videos.title: Only Good Vibes At Grinduro Hellenthal 2024 - Gravel Racing With A Smile
videos.description:
This was Grinduro 2024 at Hellenthal in the Eifel, Germany. 
We were glad to be part of the event and help out with some Race Support. 
 
https://grinduro.com/deutschland/

videos.title: SRAMtv | Gravel racing at Grinduro Germany with Miranda Miller
videos.description: What happens when you combine a gravel grinder road race and mountain bike enduro in the wettest and wildest conditions possible? SRAM athlete, Miranda Miller, finds out firsthand at the inaugural Grinduro Germany. The downhill World Champion shows us around Hellenthal, Germany in the infamous Eifel region while giving drop bars a go in her first gravel event.
tags: how to prepare for a gravel race
how to train for a gravel bike race
videos.transcript:
Hey, I was just wondering if you could tell
me what Grinduro is and what it means to you.
Just German only, I think.
Hey, I’m Miranda Miller I’m your host
of this episode of SRAMtv.
We're in Hellenthal Germany for Grinduro.
I've never raced gravel, never been to a Grinduro,
so we're gonna go find some people to kind
of tell us how it all works.
Let's go!
How many gravel events have you done in the
past?
I did my first ever gravel event was the Steamboat
Springs Gravel in 2019, then I had a two-year
hiatus - uh three years.
And I did one last weekend, well a couple
of weekends ago I did the Rancho in Spain,
it was going really well until the 130k mark
where I punctured because I didn't have tubeless,
and I didn't realize tubeless was a thing
at gravel events.
But I think this weekend I have tubeless so
for my third gravel event I'm third time lucky,
I'm feeling prepared.
Woah!
Pfff.
Way too high.
Where did you ride from?
I rode 300 kilometers and need a beer.
There it is – the man's got a beer!
So, I’m here with a World Champion, past
World Champion, who just opted out of the
Pro category.
Can you fill me in on your mindset?
Yeah, when I got the question, I just felt
it was super intimidating because, yeah, I
really did not know what to answer.
It was the first time that I really had to
answer that question after retiring and I
was like, “well, no.
Technically no.”
And what brings you to Grinduro Germany.
Well, um, the format.
I've heard really good things about this format,
and I was like, you know what we're gonna
try that out.
So, there's been a lot of talk around the
pit that you are bringing the Heat this weekend.
What do you think about that?
I think maybe German only
You are very good at riding very long distances,
aren't you?
Yes, and slow is key in long distance because
you can you can continue for days and days
and days and weeks and months, and not Years
yet.
What's your longest ride?
My longest one is I went to North Cape, so
north of Norway it was like 4,600 kilometers.
Chill…easy…easy.
What's your favorite part about Grinduro?
Well, it's fun!
Carlos, you're definitely a little more well
known for the road cycling, but uh here you
are at Grinduro Germany.
What inspired you to come here?
Have fun on the bike.
The season in Road was quite long and hard,
and so at the end of the season I talked to
the team, and I happened to think, why don't
do something different?
Going to ride gravel, you know, I think now
it's quite popular.
And enjoy cycling life in a way you that you
know is competitive and more social.
At Grinduro, we take our Prologues seriously.
So again, stand still start.
You get three attempts, and your fastest time
will be on record.
Go, go, go!
I feel like I tried harder, but I don't know
if I went faster.
It's too hard.
The first race day hammered rain and wind
all night.
So, we're going to go see if there's any casualties
in the campsite.
We came with the train all the way from Geneva
to here, and then from the train station we
rode here in the dark.
It was awesome, it was really nice.
And you camped last night?
Yeah, we camped last night I was staying alone
in the car, in the tent and I was really cold.
Ha-ha.
How was your sleep last night?
It was short and I was scared actually because
I heard a little rain coming down and I was
about to leave, and thought “come on, I
can't leave now.”
Yeah, I live one and a half hour away.
You could have gone home.
Ha yeah, I could have that’s why I stayed.
A rain party!
Pitter patter – better get at ‘er.
It was a wild one out there.
The first couple hours were actually kind
of unbelievable, you know?
It was like raining so hard and like so windy,
but at the time I was like I was warm, so
I didn't really care.
But like, I was just saying this is probably
like the longest 50k I've ever done.
Uh, yeah it didn’t help that I had a double
puncture…double puncture.
I'm curious to see like the singletrack stuff,
because if it's like if it's like grass with
a little bit of you know gravel or whatever
then that's going to be pretty grippy, but
if it's if it's blown out and it's just like
a mud chute like everything else is.
I don't know how you're gonna stop or turn…So
anyways, it's sick
Holy.
I can't ride down there.
Trying to record this on my GoPro.
This could be me dying on camera.
The day is over here at Grinduro Germany.
It was an eventful day.
Pouring rain in the morning, blue skies in
the afternoon.
It almost felt like two separate days.
It's been an interesting experience getting
to kind of meet everyone and learn how they
got here.
A common theme has been people just finding
a new way to get into nature and experience
freedom.
Let's go talk to some racers before this party
gets started.
So, Myles you race road bikes and gravel,
and you're just getting into mountain biking.
Yeah.
You're a Cat 1 racer?
Cat 1 / 2, but who's counting?
Not me.
Ha-ha
I feel like it's a balance - especially at
a race like this.
Setting your own goals for yourself about
what you want to do, and you know feel good
have fun ride.
But obviously winning is contingent on how
everybody else does as well, so I think it's
kind of this balance where you want to try
to beat other people but at the end of the
day if that doesn't go according to plan,
or someone like Carlos Verona shows up…and
you’re like, well that's like World Tour
fitness and I'm never gonna have that, at
least right now.
You kind of have to manage expectations, so
I think it's a tricky thing to do a little
bit, but I think that it also forces you to
maybe look at the day that you want to have
and just feel good about the effort that you
gave and how you rode your bike.
What are your initial impressions of gravel
in Europe?
You know, lots of competition or like crazy
roads, or what's stood out the most for you?
I mean like, what I'm most happy with gravel
riding is like, if there is a race I can compete
and it's possible to win.
It’s not like road in Europe, so I'm happy
with this and that's a big impression for
me.
It’s a thing that I can win, so I'm happy
with it.

videos.title: Grinduro Germany
videos.description:
Grinduro returns to Hellenthal in 2023! Save the dates: May 5 - 7. Entries open soon!

The Eifel is a region famous for both delighting and torturing cyclists. So no surprise that we chose the Eifel to host such a wild event as Grinduro Germany. But what exactly is Grinduro? It’s a combo of a gravel grinder road race and mountain bike enduro: one long loop on all kinds of terrain, where finishing times aren’t based on overall loop time, but four timed segments.

The routes are a mix of everything from pavement, gravel and single trail. Grinduro is held in enduro format, with four stages ridden in race mode, the rest of the tour can be enjoyed without time pressure. It's both beautiful and challenging. With a well-balanced mix of paved and unpaved, flat and hilly, fast and technical, social and competitive.

videos.title: Grinduro Germany 2023
videos.description: Check out the aftermovie of Grinduro Germany 2023. Grinduro is a weekend-long gravel cycling festival, featuring live music, camping, great food and bicycle expo in Hellenthal, the Eifel.

videos.title: GRINDURO GERMANY - A RETURN TO THE PRO CLASS!
videos.description:
Grinduro Germany was my forst epxerience with an enduro race format. With the event situated in the beautiful Hellenthal in the Eifel region I had high expectations for the weekend. Turned out to be a brutal route with all types of weather. Furthermore, an unexpected meet up with old friends and active pro racers made it a all worth it. I will be back for more!
   
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Having raced on -and offroad proffesionally for 10 years I'm now starting a new chapter in my life. Follow along as I try to give you an insight to the process of transferring into civil life.

Instagram https://www.instagram.com/annika.langvad/

Facebook https://da-dk.facebook.com/annikalangvadfanpage/
